articles.headline: In Europe, a Marriage Shows Signs of Fraying
articles.snippet: The elections in France and the government’s collapse in the Netherlands should serve as warnings for Germany, which still insists on austerity elsewhere in the euro zone.
articles.abstract: The elections in France and the government’s collapse in the Netherlands should serve as warnings for Germany, which still insists on austerity elsewhere in the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the European monetary union is something like a bad marriage, what can be done to avoid a messy and disastrous divorce?

articles.headline: U.S. Escalates Google Case by Hiring Noted Outside Lawyer
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission named a former federal prosecutor to lead its antitrust inquiry in a sign that the agency is prepared to take the Internet giant to court.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission named a former federal prosecutor to lead its antitrust inquiry in a sign that the agency is prepared to take the Internet giant to court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators escalated their antitrust investigation of Google on Thursday by hiring a prominent litigator, sending a strong signal that they are prepared to take the Internet giant to court.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: S.&P. Cuts Its Rating on Spain, Citing Debt
articles.snippet: The downgrade came with Spain emerging as a looming problem for Europe, with fears that the country will be next in line for a huge bailout, after Greece.
articles.abstract: The downgrade came with Spain emerging as a looming problem for Europe, with fears that the country will be next in line for a huge bailout, after Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s downgraded Spain’s credit rating on Thursday, saying that the country’s sovereign debt levels were too high and that its banks would need an infusion of aid as the country’s economy contracted.

articles.headline: Gingrich Is Quitting the Race (Just Give Him a Little Time)
articles.snippet: Modern candidates announce their intent to run for president on multiple occasions. Ever the innovator, Newt Gingrich has applied that ritual to dropping out.
articles.abstract: Modern candidates announce their intent to run for president on multiple occasions. Ever the innovator, Newt Gingrich has applied that ritual to dropping out.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — Newt Gingrich arrived at the Penske Racing plant here on Thursday accompanied by a large security detail protecting him from a big threat — of rain.

articles.headline: U.S. Sees Positive Signs From China on Security Issues
articles.snippet: China’s changing positions on Iran, Syria and North Korea, among others, are hailed as steps toward unity among the world’s major powers, but its motives are a mystery.
articles.abstract: China’s changing positions on Iran, Syria and North Korea, among others, are hailed as steps toward unity among the world’s major powers, but its motives are a mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When China suddenly began cutting back its purchases of oil from Iran in the last month,  officials in the Obama administration were guardedly optimistic, seeing the move as  the latest in a string of encouraging signs from Beijing on sensitive security issues  like Syria and North Korea, as well as on politically fraught economic issues like China’s exchange rate.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: On Day of Reckoning, Recalling Horror That Swallowed Liberia
articles.snippet: The soldiers of Charles G. Taylor, who was found guilty on Thursday of war crimes, ripped apart the lives of a reporter’s family members in the 1990s.
articles.abstract: The soldiers of Charles G. Taylor, who was found guilty on Thursday of war crimes, ripped apart the lives of a reporter’s family members in the 1990s.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When I heard the news Thursday that Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, had been found guilty of war crimes in Sierra Leone, I immediately telephoned one of the people whose life had been ripped apart by his soldiers: my sister Eunice, back home in Liberia.

articles.headline: Challenge for U.S. After Escape by China Activist
articles.snippet: Chen Guangcheng, a self-taught lawyer, was said to have sought refuge at the American Embassy in Beijing, potentially complicating matters for Washington ahead of a high-level meeting next week.
articles.abstract: Chen Guangcheng, a self-taught lawyer, was said to have sought refuge at the American Embassy in Beijing, potentially complicating matters for Washington ahead of a high-level meeting next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The dramatic nighttime escape of a blind rights lawyer from extralegal house arrest in his village dealt a major embarrassment to the Chinese government and left the United States, which may be sheltering him, with a new diplomatic quandary as it seeks to improve its fraught relationship with Beijing.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: U.S. Growth Slows to 2.2%, Report Says
articles.snippet: At an annual rate of 2.2 percent, growth of gross domestic product eased from the prior quarter but kept what economists have called a “sustainable” pace of recovery.
articles.abstract: At an annual rate of 2.2 percent, growth of gross domestic product eased from the prior quarter but kept what economists have called a “sustainable” pace of recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic recovery slowed more than expected early this year, raising fears of a spring slowdown for the third year in a row and giving Republicans a fresh opportunity to criticize President Obama’s policies.

articles.headline: Bribes Without Jail Time
articles.snippet: The Wal-Mart bribery allegations have the makings of a gripping criminal prosecution. But if precedent is any guide, no one is likely to be jailed.
articles.abstract: The Wal-Mart bribery allegations have the makings of a gripping criminal prosecution. But if precedent is any guide, no one is likely to be jailed.
articles.lead_paragraph: As reported in a front-page article in The New York Times this week, the Wal-Mart Mexican bribery scheme has all the makings of a gripping criminal prosecution: millions of dollars in illegal payoffs to Mexican government officials and evidence of a cover-up scheme that went all the way to Wal-Mart headquarters in Bentonville, Ark.
